Description: The terracotta head of a female saint or beneficent demon, broken from a figure, wearing a wreath framing the head and terminating in blooms (or perhaps earrings) at ear level: these are pierced through their centres. The back is plain. Hand-modelled, or the front made in a one-piece mould, the back roughly manipulated. Micaceous brown Nile silt. Traces of an overall white dressing, painted pale yellow. Details in post-firing black paint on the face, indicating a choker necklace.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: British School of Archaeology in Egypt. Found at Athribis (Atripe; Triphion) near Sohag in Upper Egypt, possibly excavated by E. Ward from the 'Coenobium of Athribis', perhaps a women's monastery (Emmel 2007: 92) near the White Monastery (Petrie et al. 1908: 13-15). Late Roman, sixth to seventh century AD. Comparanda: Near: Allen 1985: no. 102, from Karanis, dated fourth to mid-fifth century AD; Del Francia Barocus 1998: 110, no. 118, from the North Cemetery at Antinoopolis, dated fifth to seventh century AD; Petrie Museum uc48242, from Memphis.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3387)
Adams 1977 / Egyptian objects in the Victoria and Albert Museum (p.45)
Acquisition name: Transferred from: Victoria and Albert Museum (Department of Ceramics)
